[Sesame Workshop](https://apnews.com/article/sesame-street-elevate-prize-foundation-catalyst-award-523180a38f00982924dcc57035fab383) regained control of its Elmo account on the X platform Monday after a hacker gained access and posted a string of racist and antisemitic messages.

“Elmo’s X account was compromised by an unknown hacker who posted disgusting messages, including antisemitic and racist posts,” Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit [behind “Sesame Street”](https://apnews.com/article/sesame-street-netflix-move-pbs-b74920f423e9790973b59735689696c2) and Elmo, said in a statement Monday.

The account was compromised over the weekend and instead of the usual posts of encouragement and kindness, Elmo’s 650,000 followers were given antisemitic threats and a profane reference to the [Jeffrey Epstein sex trafficking investigation](https://apnews.com/article/jeffrey-epstein-justice-department-pam-bondi-03fbcd024f631440f7ed62b3c6927db3). Those tweets were soon deleted.

X did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Elmo’s social media account has lately become a place for mental health awareness. Last year, the red fuzzy monster, eternally 3 ½, [caused a sensation](https://apnews.com/article/pop-culture-2024-c985d4b171608dcc00bf07c3989512d3) when he asked: “Elmo is just checking in! How is everybody doing?” It prompted responses from then-President Joe Biden and Chance the Rapper.
